title: Jackson's final position at the end of the march
Jackson's attack
description: At about 5:30 p.m., after almost ten hours of marching, Jackson's force of just over 20,000 men attacked eastward along Plank Road, completely surprising the soldiers of Howard's right flank, many of whom were sitting down eating dinner when the Second Corps started the assault. In spite of Maj. Gen. Carl Schurz's skillful attempt to reorient the angle of the Union right flank in response to the attack and Howard's last-minute efforts to organize a coherent defense of the position, Jackson's corps quickly moved along a roughly 1.25 mile stretch of Plank Road to within about a mile of Chancellorsville, completely scattering the Union defenses as they went.

title: Jackson's flanking march
description:
Jackson started moving southwest on a 12-mile, roundabout flanking march on Furnace Road with his corps of 28,000 men between 7 and 8 in the morning. Considered one of Lee's most daring tactical decisions in the war, Jackson was separated from the rest of Lee's army had to completely circle around the (much larger) Union position to the north around Chancellorsville and the Wilderness without revealing his position.

Meanwhile, Lee was also gambling that Jubal Early would be able to successfully hold off Sedgwick, Reynolds, and Gibbon to the east at Fredericksburg - a Union breakthrough there would have left Lee's comparatively small force without the support of the Second Corps, and pinned on two sides by much larger Federal forces.

title: "Route of Flanking Movement of Jackson's Corps"
Jackson's flanking march
description:
Jackson started moving southwest on a 12-mile, roundabout flanking march on Furnace Road with his corps of 28,000 men between 7 and 8 in the morning. Considered one of Lee's most daring tactical decisions in the war, Jackson was separated from the rest of Lee's army had to completely circle around the (much larger) Union position to the north around Chancellorsville and the Wilderness without revealing his position.

Meanwhile, Lee was also gambling that Jubal Early would be able to successfully hold off Sedgwick, Reynolds, and Gibbon to the east at Fredericksburg - a Union breakthrough there would have left Lee's comparatively small force without the support of the Second Corps, and pinned on two sides by much larger Federal forces.

title: Lee, Jackson, and Hotchkiss plan the flanking march at the intersection of Plank Road and Furnace Road
Sickles sees Jackson's march
description: After Brig. Gen. David B. Birney spotted Jackson's columns marching along Furnace Road, Daniel E. Sickles, the corps commander in charge of the Union position near Catherine's Furnace, reported the movement to back to Hooker at GHQ in Chancellorsville. Hooker suspected either a retreat or a flanking attempt, and ordered Major General Oliver O. Howard on the right flank (Jackson's ultimate target) to prepare for a flanking attack and instructed Sickles to approach Furnace Road and mount a more sustained attempt to block the march.

title: Birney and Birdan attempt to block Jackson's movement
description:
After getting approval from Hooker, Sickles sent the division of Brig. Gen. David B. Birney and two battalions of Col. Hiram Bedram's sharpshooters south towards Furnace Road to try to interfere with Jackson's march around the Union positions around Chancellorsville and the Wilderness.

By the time Birney and Bedram arrived at Furnace Road, though, the greater part of Jackson's corps had already passed the bend in the road where the Union troops intersected with the road, and Jackson had sent the 23rd Georgia Infantry back to tie up the small Union offensive. The 23rd resisted Birney and Bedram for most of the day, and succeeded in preventing any noteworthy damage to Jackson's force.

title: Howard fails to prepare for the Confederate assault
description:
When Hooker was first alerted to the possibility that the Confederate army was flanking around the Union positions at Chancellorsville and the Wilderness, he sent an order to Maj. Gen. Oliver O. Howard, who was in command of the right flank of the Union position, the presumtive target of Jackson's movement along Furnace Road.

Although Howard had responded that he was taking action to prepare for an assault, the position was almost completely undefended when Jackson's corps moved into position along the Old Turnpike between three and four in the afternoon. The Union right flank was not demarcated or protected by any kind of geographic formation, and Howards lines were facing generally south, along Orange Plank Road (the route that Jackson originally picked for the assault, only to abandon when he realized that the Union forces were fortified along the road and prepared for contact). The only Union defense specifically focused on the right was a pair of cannons pointing out into the woods.

title: Final Confederate position at nightfall
description: As darkness fell, the Confederate assault became increasingly disjointed and confused as it moved through the woods near Old Schoolhouse. The advance was halted and the lines reformed around 9 o'clock, just as the front line approached the positions of Sickles' men, who had returned from their efforts earlier in the day to halt Jackson's flanking march and taken up the high ground on Hazel Grove. In the aftermath of Jackson's assault, Sickles' force was the only significant barrier between the Second Corps and Lee's troops to the southeast of Chancellorsville.

title: Jackson shot by friendly fire
description: As Jackson returned a late-night scouting expedition along the Turnpike, sharpshooters on the Confederate lines mistook him and his companions for Union cavalry and fired, hitting Jackson in the arm. The limb was amputated later that night, and Jackson died from pneumonia eight days later on Map 10.

title: Sickles moves back to fortify Hazel Grove
description:
After the fizzled attempt to interfere with the movement of the Second Corps in the morning, Sickles' men retreated northward and assumed a strong position on the high ground at Hazel Grove, where they would soon become the only barrier between Jackson's triumphant Second Corps and Lee's army to the southeast.

At the end of Jackson's offensive, Sickles tried to mount a direct counteroffensive at about 11 p.m., but was driven back by Confederate artillery and retired for the day.

title: Jackson's flanking march
description:
Jackson started moving southwest on a 12-mile, roundabout flanking march on Furnace Road with his corps of 28,000 men between 7 and 8 in the morning. Considered one of Lee's most daring tactical decisions in the war, Jackson was separated from the rest of Lee's army had to completely circle around the (much larger) Union position to the north around Chancellorsville and the Wilderness without revealing his position.

Meanwhile, Lee was also gambling that Jubal Early would be able to successfully hold off Sedgwick, Reynolds, and Gibbon to the east at Fredericksburg - a Union breakthrough there would have left Lee's comparatively small force without the support of the Second Corps, and pinned on two sides by much larger Federal forces.

title: Early and Barksdale hold off Sedgwick at Fredericksburg
description:
Over the course of the week leading up to Chancellorsville, Lee had decided to try to stop Hooker's army from consolidating and challenging the significantly smaller Confederate army in a single pitched battle. Lee considered the larger force approaching from the northwest to be the greater concern, and decided that it would be easier to stall out the smaller force under John Sedgwick approaching from the east at Fredericksburg and focus the majority of the Confederate army on the challenge at Chancellorsville.

As Lee moved west towards the town, he left behind William Barksdale's on Marye's Heights above the town and positioned Jubal Early to on Prospect Hill to the south. These fortifications would prove essential over the course of the day on May 2 - with Jackson's Second Corps marching around the main Union force at Chancellorsville and the Wilderness, Lee's smaller force, now reduced by the two successive splits, would have been completely exposed to Sedgwick's force moving over the Rappahannock.

title: Hooker's "double envelopment" of the Confederate army
description:
In the aftermath of the chaotic upheaval in leadership that rocked the Union army after the disastrous defeat at the first Battle of Fredericksburg in December of 1862, Joseph Hooker, the newly-appointed general, decided to mount an offensive against Lee with a risky "double envelopment" movement that would squeeze the Confederates out of their position south of the Rappahannock.

Hooker would lead about 40,000 men in three corps would march northwest from Falmouth and cross the Rappahannock at Kelly's Ford. Another 40,000 troops, under the command of Sedgwick, would go south and cross the river below Fredericksburg. Meanwhile, Hooker planned to send his cavalry on raids far south of Chancellorsville in hopes of cutting off Lee's supply lines, weakening his rear guard, and ultimately scaring him back into a defensive position around Richmond, where it was thought that the Union army would have a better chance of provoking Lee into a decisive battle that would reward the Union's superior numbers and supplies.

title: Lee splits his army
description: In response to Hooker's "double-envelopment," Lee decided to match Hooker's two-pronged formation by splitting his own forces and preventing the Union from reuniting around the Army of Northern Virginia at a single location. Early and Barksdale were sent east to hold Sedgwick's brigade at bay, and Lee moved to the west towards Chancellorsville with Jackson's Second Corps.

title:
April 27 - 30
Hooker splits his army and tries to "double envelop" Lee with two forces, one approaching from the north by way of Chancellorsville and the other from the east at Fredericksburg.

April 30
Lee splits his army, sending Jubal Early to hold off Sedgwick at Fredericksburg and moving the rest of his force west to engage Hooker at Chancellorsville.

May 2, 7:30 a.m.
Lee splits his army again, sending Jackson's Second Corps on a 12-mile, 10-hour flanking march around the Union positions around Chancellorsville and the Wilderness

May 2, 11:00 a.m.
Sickles sees columns of Jackson's Second Corps marching along Furnace Road, alerts Hooker at GHQ in Chancellorsville, and mounts an ineffective assault to try to impede Jackson's progress.

May 2, 3:00 p.m.
Jackson first planned to make his attack by way of Orange Plank Road, but discovers that such an attack would strike the Union flank at an angle instead of end on, so he decides to continue north for another two miles and attack along the Old Turnpike.

May 2, 4:00 p.m.
The Second Corps completes its flanking march and moves into position along Old Turnpike.

May 2, 5:30 p.m.
The 20,000 men in Jackson's Second Corps attack the Union right flank along the Old Turnpike, finding Oliver Howard's troops completely unprepared for the assault.

May 2, 9:30 p.m.
Jackson is shot in the arm while returning from a late-night reconnaissance mission to scout out the possibility of renewing the assault on the Union forces.

title:
May 3, 4:00 a.m.
Hooker orders Sickles to abandon Hazel Grove and take up a position along the Plank Road.
Sickles abandons Hazel Grove
description: Not realizing that Sickles' brigade on Hazel Grove was the only remaining piece of the Union army standing between the triumphant Second Corps and Lee's force to the east, in the early morning of May 3 Hooker ordered Sickles to abandon the hill and retreat to a perpendicular position along the Plank Road, where he would be in position to directly resist the movement of the Second Corps towards Hooker's headquarters at the Chancellorsville crossroads.

title:
May 3, 5:00 a.m.
Archer skirmishes with the rear of Sickles' brigade and establishes a Confederate artillery position on Hazel Grove.
Alexander's artillery batteries on Hazel Grove
description: After Brig. Gen. James A. Archer captured the high ground at Hazel Grove, Col. Porter Alexander moved in and set up a 30-gun artillery battery pointing out to the northwest at the Chancellorsville crossroads.

title:
May 3, ~ 3:00 a.m.
J.E.B. Stuart, Jackson's replacement at the head of the Second Corps, organizes his three divisions along Plank Road in advance of the morning attack.
Brig. Gen. Robert E. Rodes

title:
May 3, 5:30 a.m.
Stuart, Andreson, and McLaws resume the attack Chancellorsville from the west and south.

May 3, 9:30 a.m.
Union forces abandon Fairview and start to retreat north towards the Rappahannock.

May 3, 10:00 a.m.
The two halves of the Confederate army reunite in victory at the Chancellorsville crossroads and Lee rides in to survey the scene.

May 3, 9:15 a.m.
Hooker is briefly knocked unconscious when a Confederate cannon round hits the Union headquarters at Chancellorsville.

May 2, ~ 9:00 p.m.
Hooker orders Sedgwick to cross the Rappahannock and march towards Chancellorsville in an effort to reinforce his position in the aftermath of Jackson's attack.
Sedgwick crosses the Rappahannock
description: Late on May 2, after Jackson's attack drove the Union army into a defensive position around Chancellorsville, Hooker sent an order to Sedgwick instructing him to cross the Rappahannock and march west along the Chancellorsville road, hoping that Swdgwick's columns would arrive in time to relieve the tattered force entrenched in the earthworks around the Chancellor mansion.

title:
May 3, ~10:00 a.m.
Early, Barksdale, and Hays resist Union efforts to break through the Confederate lines at the stone wall on Marye's Heights.
Early returns to Fredericksburg to head off Sedgwick's advance
description: On the morning of May 2, Early received a confusing message from Lee's headquarters that Early interpreted as an instruction to start marching east towards Chancellorsville. Early started moving southwest along Mine Road, but then turned around and marched back to Fredericksburg when William Barksdale sent word that Sedgwick was moving to attack the Union lines on the east of the Rappahannock.

title: Hays and Barksdale defend the sone wall on Marye's Heights
Union soldiers gathering wounded see an opportunity to break through the Confederate line
description: After two failed attempt to breach the Confederate fortifications on Marye's Heights, a group of Union soldiers with a white flag were allowed to approach the wall under the pretense of gathering the wounded. As they worked, though, they noticed that Hays' and Barksdale's lines were extremely thin, and reported back to Sedgwick that a third, concerted assault on the position would have a good chance of breaking through and opening up the road the Chancellorsville.

title:
May 3, ~10:30 a.m.
Union soldiers gathering the wounded near the stone wall see an opportunity to break through Barksdale's defenses.

May 3, 11:00 a.m.
Sedgwick breaks through the Confederate lines on Marye's Heights.
Sedgwick breaks through Barksdale's and Hays' lines and starts to move towards Chancellorsville
description: After Union troops collecting the bodies of the dead near the stone wall on Marye's Heights noticed how flimsy the Confederate line seemed to be after the first two failed attempts, Sedgwick mobilized a third assault on Hays and Barksdale that broke through and opened up the road to Chancellorsville.

title:
May 3, 11:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m.
Wilcox delays Sedgwick as he marches along Plank Road towards Lee at Chancellorsville.
Wilcox delays Sedgwick's advance
description: As Sedgwick's columns started the march along Plank Road towards Chancellorsville, the Alabama brigade of Brig. Gen. Cadmus M. Wilcox mounted a series of small actions against the Union columns, slowing them considerably and eventually bringing them to a halt near Salem Church when McLaws division arrived from Chancellorsville.

title:
May 3, Noon - 4:00 p.m.
McLaws marches east from Chancellorsville to halt Sedgwick's advance.
McLaws marches east to challenge Sedgwick's advance
description: After Sedgwick broke through Hays' and Barksdale's line at Fredericksburg, McLaws took three brigades and stared marching east along Plank Road to intercept the approaching Union columns before they could threaten the hard-won Confederate position at Chancellorsville.

title: Wilcox and McLaws unite to form a line near Salem Church
description: After mounting two smaller efforts to impede the progress of Sedgwick's march towards Chancellorsville, Wilcox combined his brigade with three brigades under the command of Maj. Gen. Lafayette McLaws to form a force of 10,000, lined up perpendicular to Plank Road near Salem Church.

title:
May 3, 5:30 p.m.
Brooks fails to break the Confederate line at Salem Church.
Brooks fails to break through the Confederate line at Salem Church
description:
At 5:30 p.m., after hours of artillery fire back and forth, two brigades under the command of Brig. Gen. William T. Brooks attacked the long Confederate line running north to south above and below Plank Road. The assault failed, and Sedgwick's force was stalled for the night well short of it's objective at Chancellorsville, which remained in Confederate hands.

By nightfall, 21,357 men had been killed during the day's fighting, making May 3 the second bloodiest day of the war after the Battle of Antietam.

title: Hooker protects his line of retreat
description: After abandoning the Chancellorsville crossroads the day before, Hooker spent Monday, May 4 entrenched in a horseshoe shaped line along Mineral Spring Road, extending almost as far north as the Rappahannock.

title:
May 4, All day
Hooker retreats to a defensive position south of the Rappahannock and declines to mount a counter-offensive against Lee's force.

May 4, Morning
Seeing that Hooker was not threatening action from the north, Lee sends Anderson to help with the fight against Sedgwick to the east.

May 4, Mid-morning
Lee and Anderson march east on River Road to join Early and McClaws in the fight against Sedgwick.
Anderson marches to Fredericksburg
description: Seeing that Hooker's lines were bunkered down along Mineral Road and not preparing for an attempt to retake the Chancellorsville crossroads, Lee decided to take the division of Maj. Gens. Richard H. Anderson on a long march on River Road to connect with Jubal Early and Lafayette McLaws and resume the effort to drive Sedgwick back to the Rappahannock.

title:
May 4, Mid-morning
Jubal Early retakes Marye's Heights and solidifies a Confederate line on three sides of Sedgwick's position.

May 4, 12 - 5:00 p.m.
Anderson and McLaws fail to capitalize on Early's morning success by tarrying in their efforts to get their forces in position for attack.

May 4, 6:00 p.m.
Early, McLaws, and Anderson attack and force Sedgwick north to the banks of the river.

May 5, Midnight - 4:00 a.m.
Sedgwick retreats across the Rappahannock at Bank's Ford, effectively ending the Union's campaign.
Lee attacks Sedgwick and forces the Union back across the Rappahannock
description:
After wasting most of the afternoon waiting for McLaws and Anderson to get their divisions into position to attack Sedgwick's position from the west, south, and east, Lee started the attack on Sedgwick's horseshoe-shaped line around 6:00 in the evening.

In spite of tepid performances from Anderson and McLaws, Early managed to break the Union lines and push Sedgwick's force to the river by nightfall.

title: Sedgwick retreat across the Rappahannock in the early hours of May 5
<font face="Arial, Verdana" size="2">Moss Neck, Caroline Co. Va.</font>
<font face="Arial, Verdana" size="2">My Dear Little Nelly</font>
I promised to write you a letter ...
description: I promised to write you a letter, when I was at home, so I will take a few minutes this evening and make my promise good.

title: I left home Sunday ...
description: I left home Sunday, you know, and went to New Hope that day, the next day I went across the Blue Ridge Mountain and the next day went on to Orange Court House and then travelled nearly all day through the woods, and where the road is sandy, and then got to where the army was the next day, on the Mattapony River.

title: If you look in the large atlas ...
description: If you look in the large atlas, in Virginia, you will find four rivers, the Mat, the Ta, the Po, and the Ny and they all come together to make the Mat-ta-pony river, near which we had out camp, among the long-leaved pine trees, the evergreen holly bushes, with prickles on the edges of the leaves; and the Sweet Gum trees that look as though they were winged, or rather the little limbs look so, for the bark projects on each side and causes the winged appearance I spoke of.

title: We had a cold snow storm ...
description: We had a cold snow storm while we were at Guinea Station near the Mattapony river, but out cloth houses were very comfortable, for we had a stove, with the pipe sticking out of the door, or the slit in the sides of the tent, that serves for a door.

title: Not far from our tent ...
description: Not far from our tent was a pretty stream of water, with a bottom of white sand and white and yellow quartz pebbles, that look very prettily through the clear water.

title: You never saw such fences ...
description: You never saw such fences as they have here, they call them wattled fences - they throw up a ridge of dirt, leaving a ditch on one side, then they drive a row of stakes nearly six inches apart along the top of the ridge, and then they get long, slender cedar limbs and weave them in among the stakes, like splints of a basket, and so make a light fence 3 or 4 feet high - all the fences here are wattled ones - and then they have cedar trees growing up by the sices of the fences, and we sometimes go a long ways through two rows of pretty ever-green trees.

title: The country here is very flat ...
description: The country here is very flat, with a good many swamps, but no very high hills, and a great many pine forests - where the trees are all pines, and very thick.

title: I saw a very pretty grave yard ...
description: I saw a very pretty grave yard the other day, made by planting cedar trees in a ring and they had grown up thick and come together at the top of the limbs had been kept cut off on the inside, and there was a place where you could go in, and where in it was like a green house, shaped like half an egg, and the ground on the inside was thickly covered with myrtle, and there were several graves with nice marble slabs - on the outside it looked like one big tree.

title: I must now tell you about a battle ...
description: I must now tell you about a battle we had last Saturday, the 13th of Dec., and I will make a little map for you to look at and see how the armies were located when they fought.

title: Look at the map I have made for you.
description: Look at the map I have made for you.

title: The roads are put down ...
description: The roads are put down red lines, out troops in black lines and the Yankees in the blue ones.

title: Our army was on the hills ...
description: Our army was on the hills in front of the Mine and Telegraph Roads, mostly in the woods, and we had cannons where you see a black line with a dot on each side.

title: The enemy came across the river ...
description: The enemy came across the river on pontoon, or broad bridges made so - of boards fastened in the streams with planks laid across them, at Fredericksburg and at the mouth of Deep Runn, and then came up into the flat where the short blue lines are and they had cannons where I have made short blue lines with dots beside them ...

title: ... when they came up towards the woods ...
description: ... when they came up towards the woods where out men were we fired a great many thousand guns at them and they fired at us, and so we did for a long time and we at last drove them back, having killed a large number of them and wounding many more - we had a good many killed and wounded too, but not as many as they did, for we were protected by the woods ...

title: Now they have gone away ...
description: Now they have gone away across the river, and we must thank the good Lord that he enabled us to whip them and drive them away, for they would come and destroy us and our country if they could.

title: We are now on a neck of land ...
description: We are now on a neck of land in a big bend of the river, called Moss neck - there is a great deal of pretty moss growing here.

title: I am glad you say ...
description: I am glad you say so many good lessons, as your Ma tells me - be a good girl and learn all you can - help your Ma and be kind to every body and always good-natured and be sure to love God and do right.

title: Kiss your sister Anna for Pa -
description: Kiss your sister Anna for Pa -

title: So good night, my daughter
description: So good night, my daughter

title: From Your Pa - Jed Hotchkiss
description: From Your Pa - Jed Hotchkiss

Sketch of the Battle of Fredericksburg, December 13
description:
Shows names of some residents.

Relief shown by hachures.

Pen-and-ink and pencil (some col.) over a 2-inch pencil grid on gray tracing paper, mounted on cloth.

Reference: LC Civil War maps (2nd ed.), H123

Includes index to Confederate divisions' positions.

In pencil on verso: 95.

Scale [1:31,680].

In the actual letter, Hotchkiss drew the sketch of the battlefield at the bottom of the third page, rotated about 90 degrees clockwise away from a standard cardinal orientation with north pointing towards the top of the page. Here, to accurately align the sketch with the formal battle maps without turning the rest of the letter to an unreadable angle, we have cut the image of the third page in half and rotated the section with map to a normal orientation.

It's not clear why Hotchkiss chose to make the sketch with east pointing up - all of his other maps of the Fredericksburg area, both pertaining to the first battle in 1862 and the nearby Battle of Chancellorsville in the summer of the next year, are oriented normally.

Probably, Hotchkiss rotated everything to the right to make it fit onto the limited space at the bottom of the page. Since the battle action around Fredericksburg was spread out over a long north-south line, and thus was "taller" than wide, Hotchkiss could have rotated the view to make it fit more easily into the relatively narrow strip of open space at the bottom of the page.

title: Jackson's Second Corps
description: Jackson's Second Corps formed a long, thin line of troops southeast of the town and below Deep Run, concealed behind the edge of the woods that ran along the low ridgeline west of the Rappahannock.

title: Confederate artillery batteries behind the stone wall on Marye's Heights
The stone wall
description:
Elsewhere in the sketch, Hotchkiss sticks pretty close to his normal technique of representing troop positions with small line segments here (see the dashed black lines southeast of here that represent the defensive lines of Longstreet and Jackson).

Here, though, the mark is noticeably longer than the other lines on the map, and, based on its position just to the north of Telegraph Road, it's possible that this was Hotchkiss's representation of the famous stone wall that McLaws and Ransom made into one of the most effective defensive positions in the entire war.

The carnage that unfolded in front of the wall over the course of Burnside's successive assaults on the position was an incredibly humiliating defeat for the Union and a great triumph for the Army of Northern Virginia, and it seems likely that Hotchkiss would have worked it into the sketch.

title: Pontoon bridges across the Rappahannock
description:
(Click to expand.)

On December 11 and 12, Union army floated a series of pontoon bridges across the Rappahannock near Fredericksburg and further south at the position marked here on the sketch. Confederate snipers in Fredericksburg managed to significantly slow the progress of the Federal engineers at the crossings leading directly into the town, forcing the brigade of Col. Norman J. Hall to cross the river in advance of the army and clear out the small Confederate force scattered throughout the town.

The division of Maj. Gen. William B. Franklin crossed at the bridges marked here, where there was virtually no initial resistance from the Confederate line, which remained mostly concealed behind the treeline west of the river.

title: Union charges on Marye's Heights
description:
After the Union army failed to capitalize on the temporary successes of the morning assaults on Confederate lines south of the town near Massaponax Creek, Burnside turned his attention to the left end of Longstreet's Corps, lined up on the slopes of Marye's Heights, where he hoped to break through and descend on Jackson's force from the north.

Meanwhile, the Confederate lines, under the leadership of Ransom and McLaws, had established an extremely strong defensive position behind a shoulder-high stone wall on a small, sunken road connecting Telegraph Road and Orange Plank road, running lengthwise along the foot of the slope leading up to Marye's Heights.

Over the course of the day, Burnside ordered a series of 14 separate Union charges across the half-mile, open field between the western edge of the town and the stone wall, all of which were decimated down by the lines of Confederate riflemen and artillery stacked up behind the wall on the slope of Marye's Heights, in many cases with Union casualty rates close to 50% within individual divisions.

Despite the immediate and devastating failure of these assaults, Burnside continued to order charge after charge across the field. By the end of the day, the Union army lost between 6,000 to 8,000 infantrymen in front of the wall, one of the most devastating outcomes for the Army of the Potomac in the entire war.

title: Gibbon and Meade attack the Confederate right
description:
As Brig. Gen. John Gibbon and Maj. Gen. George Meade begin their assault, they happened to funnel their columns into the marshy gap in the ridgeline that had been left unprotected by the Second Corps, which allowed the Union assault to successfully flank the divisions of Brig. Gens. James Lane, James Archer, and Maxcy Gregg.

These advances were largely squandered, though by the tarrying of Brig. Gen. John Gibbon, who refused to allow Brig. Gen. Nelson Taylor to send in a bayonet charge against Lane's brigade to assist Gibbon and Meade and secure the terrain that had been gained in the initial assault.

By the time Gibbon did move forward at 1:30 p.m., three successive waves of Union attacks were stalled by Confederate artillery. By mid-afternoon, Jubal Early's division mounted a counterattack against Gibbon's lines below the ridgeline, and all of the Union's gains from earlier in the afternoon were ceded back to the Second Corps.

title: Albemarle County, Virginia by Jed. Hotchkiss, Top. Eng.
description:
Scale 1:126,720.

Reference: LC Civil War maps (2nd ed.), H275

description:
In the actual letter, Hotchkiss drew the sketch of the battlefield at the bottom of the third page, rotated about 90 degrees clockwise away from a standard cardinal orientation with north pointing towards the top of the page. Here, to accurately align the sketch with the formal battle maps without turning the rest of the letter to an unreadable angle, we have cut the image of the third page in half and rotated the section with map to a normal orientation.

It's not clear why Hotchkiss chose to make the sketch with east pointing up - all of his other maps of the Fredericksburg area, both pertaining to the first battle in 1862 and the nearby Battle of Chancellorsville in the summer of the next year, are oriented normally.

Probably, Hotchkiss rotated everything to the right to make it fit onto the limited space at the bottom of the page. Since the battle action around Fredericksburg was spread out over a long north-south line, and thus was "taller" than wide, Hotchkiss could have rotated the view to make it fit more easily into the relatively narrow strip of open space at the bottom of the page.

title: Longstreet's Corps
description:
Further north along the low ridgeline running parallel to the river, Longstreet's Corps had formed a defensive line on Marye's Heights, a cluster of four small hills immediately southwest of the town.

Near the foot of the gentle incline leading up to the hills, a small road connecting Telegraph Road and Orange Plank Road (not marked in the sketch) was lined on one side with a shoulder-high stone wall, which provided a nearly impregnable defensive position for Confederate riflemen facing out over the couple hundred yards of open field leading up to the edge of the town.

title: Introduction: Hotchkiss at Fredericksburg
description:
On the evening of December 17, 1862, Jedediah Hothckiss wrote a short letter from his campsite with the Confederate army near Moss Neck, a sharp bend in the Rappahannock river south of the town of Fredericksburg. Four days before, on the 13th of December, Hotchkiss had watched the Battle of Fredericksburg play out on the banks of the river as the Confederate forces under Jackson and Longstreet had successfully defended the ridgeline west of the town and driven the Union army back across the river to the winter refuge at Falmouth.

Hotchkiss was a schoolteacher and civilian cartographer by trade. Born and educated in New York, he started a career as a schoolteacher in Pennsylvania before moving to Augusta Country, Virginia, in 1847 and establishing the Mossy Creek Academy near Bridgewater. Hotchkiss started making maps on an amateur basis during his explorations of the Shenandoah Valley around his home, and the hobby quickly grew into a minor business and lifelong passion that would define his participation in events during and after the Civil War.

At the start of the war, Hotchkiss joined the Confederate Army as a cartographer and produced maps of the West Virginia mountains for Brig. Gen. Richard B. Garnett, and later mapped the region around Rich Mountain to assist with Lee's planned campaign in the region. After returning home to recover from typhoid fever in the first months of 1862, Hotchkiss returned to the army in March and became the chief topographical engineer for the Valley Region, reporting directly to Maj. Gen. Thomas "Stonewall" Jackson.

In 1862, Hotchkiss was the only person who has ever produced accurate and systematic maps of the Shenandoah Valley, and Jackson instructed him to start by producing a single, large map of the region to assist with the design of troop movements, supply lines, and battle plans. Hotchkiss worked closely with Jackson over the course of the next year during the Valley Campaign, the Northern Virginia Campaign, the Maryland Campaign, the Battle of Fredericksburg, and finally at the Battle of Chancellorsville, where Hotchkiss played a key role in discovering and mapping the route of the famous 14-mile flanking march that resulted in one of the most dramatic tactical victories of the entire war. Jackson was killed the night after the attack by Confederate sharpshooters who mistook him for Union cavalry as he rode back from a scouting trip.

Six months before, on December 17, 1862, Hotchkiss was camped near Jackson's headquarters on the Rappahannock, working long hours to produce a collection of detailed maps of the Battle of Fredericksburg that Jackson needed to include as part of an official report on the outcome of his campaign to the Confederate war department in Richmond. Hotchkiss wrote this letter to his daughter, Nelly Hotchkiss, on a single piece of paper, scored and folded town the middle to form four small pages on the front and back of the two folds, which now resides in a collection of Hotchkiss' correspondence at the Small Special Collections Library at the University of Virginia.

title: Movement to Battle
description:
Two months before, in early November, Lincoln had replaced McClellan as the head of the Union army with Ambrose Burnside, who he hoped would move more aggressively to defeat the Confederate army and bring the war to an end. Instead of following Lincoln's instructions to focus on beating Lee's army, though, Burnside moved his army to a position on the eastern banks of the Rappahannock River and drew up plans to march south from the river and end the war by occupying the Confederate capitol at Richmond. Lincoln, eager for any kind of forward progress after what had been widely perceived as the timidity and inaction of McClellan's tenure, acquiesced to Burnside's plan.

As Burnside's troops filed into position on the far side of the river, Lee made preparations to block the Union advance and protect the capitol by moving the Army of Northern Virginia into a long defensive formation running along the low ridgeline west of the Rappahannock. Hotchkiss had left the army and returned to his home in Churchville to recover from an illness. Eager to have the advantage of Hotchkiss' maps as he prepared for the looming conflict near Fredericksburg, Jackson sent orders on November 28 requesting that Hotchkiss report for duty at the Orange County Courthouse as soon as possible.

Here, Hotchkiss describes the journey from his home in Churchville to the small town on New Hope, and then across the "Blue Ridge Mountain" and through the hills on eastern side of the ridgeline as he works his way to Orange Court House. Hotchkiss left Churchville on on Sunday, November 30, two days after Jackson summoned him, and arrived in Orange the next day on the 1st of December. From there, it appears that he "travelled nearly all day through the woods" and arrived at Jackson's headquarters on December 2nd, presumably at or near the encampment at Guinea Station, which is mentioned on the next page.

Depending on the specific route that Hotchkiss took between New Hope and Orange on his way over the Shenandoah ridgeline, the linear distance from Churchville to Guinea Station is around 100 miles, or around 125 to 150 miles on horseback.

title: Meade breaks through on the Confederate right
Gap in the Confederate defensive line
Early and Taliaferro block Meade's advance
Hotchkiss Describes the Battle
description:
After a few paragraphs on the second and third pages describing the scene around his campsite (the quartz pebbles in a nearby stream, an unusual style of fencing built around Fredericksburg, a pretty graveyard formed by a ring of trees), Hotchkiss switches gears abruptly in the middle of the third page and starts to describe the Battle of Fredericksburg: "I must now tell you about a battle we has last Saturday, the 13th of December, and I will make a little map for you to look at and see how the armies were located and where they fought."

The appearance of the pen stroke changes immediately after this sentence, indicating that Hotchkiss stopped writing, drew the sketch of the battle at the bottom of the page, and then finished writing the letter, perhaps with a different pen. Oddly, the map itself, sketched out crudely with what appears to have been gray, blue, and red pencils and small bit of blank ink, is rotated 90 degrees clockwise from the standard cardinal orientation with north pointing upwards - the top of the page is almost exactly due west relative to the map.

Probably, Hotchkiss rotated the map to make it fit well in the rectangular portion paper remaining at the bottom of the third page. The long, seven mile defensive line formed by Longstreet's corps on Marye's Heights and Jackson's Second Corps in the woods south of the town resulted in a battle spread out over a narrow strip of ground between the river and the ridgeline. Spatially, the action was "taller" than "wide," and Hotchkiss probably didn't think he could squeeze the entire north-to-south distance between Fredericksburg and Hamilton's Crossing into the vertical space left on the sheet of paper. - Here, we have split the portion of the third page containing the sketch off into a separate image georeferenced it against a modern, real-geography tile set.

title: The Battle Sketch
description:
Even though Hotchkiss never created another map of the Fredericksburg region at this orientation (maps exist that are rotated a quarter-turn in the other direction, with the top of the map pointing east and Fredericksburg at the right of the frame), the sketch is remarkably accurate when georectified and positioned in comparison to formal maps drawn up after the battle. Drag the timeline back to December 13th to see the same stretch of the Rappahannock as represented in a formal, post-action map drawn by William Willis Blackford. Drag back to the 11th and 12th to see a pair of rough pre-battle maps by Hotchkiss that sketch out the key roads, railroads, and topographical features of the landscape around the town.

Zoom in on specific areas and drag the timeline back and forth to compare the different maps. Note especially the representations of the two major areas of action on the 13th - Meade's assault on the Confederate left near Hamilton's Crossing and the infamous series of Union charges against Longstreet's defensive line behind the stone wall due west of Fredericksburg near the top left of the map frame.

The sketch is remarkably accurate, and it arguably contains even more detail than what Hotchkiss specifically describes in the text of the letter. The anomalously long ink marking at the top left corresponds almost exactly with the geographic position of the stone wall, and the misaligned position of the left-most line of troops in the sketch of the position of the Second Corps could conceivably have been Hotchkiss' representation of the gap in the Confederate line that allowed Meade's brigade to break through and execute a series of damaging flanking attacks during the first half of the day. (Follow the numbered waypoints on Blackford's battle map for a more detailed description of the action.)

title: A Confederate Worldview
description: The letter traces a fascinating arc from the playful sweetness of the starting paragraphs through the casual, understated description of the battle, and then finally to the last sentence of the third-to-last paragraph, where Hotchkiss - originally a schoolteacher - slips into a didactic tone and offers up a haunting distillation of the confederate construction of the north as a military aggressor: "Now they have gone away across the river, and we must thank the good lord that he enabled us to whip them and drive them away, for they would come and destroy us and our country if they could."

title: Early pushes Gibbon and Meade back to the railroad

description:
In November of 1862, Lincoln was eager reinvigorate the Army of the Potomac after what was perceived to be a series of missed opportunities and demonstrate to the northern electorate his administration's ability to effectively prosecute the war. In spite of his success in stopping Lee's army at the Battle of Antietam, George McClellan was considered timid and insufficiently aggressive, especially relative to the performances of the nimble Confederate armies that had managed to make short-lived incursions into Union territories in Kentucky and Maryland.

Lincoln replaced McClellan with Ambrose Burnside, who assumed command on November 7 with instructions from the administration to focus exclusively on beating Lee's army in the field, preferably by way of a direct attack on Lee's position via the Orange and Alexandria Railroad. Instead, Burnside did just the opposite and drew up an ambitious battle plan that involved feigning an offensive to the southwest in the direction of Gordonsville or Orange Court House, only then to move quickly to the southeast, cross the Rappahannock River near Fredericksburg, and sprint down the Richmond-Fredericksburg railroad towards the Confederate capitol. After vigorous internal debate in the administration, Lincoln eventually acquiesced to the plan, if only out of impatience for some kind of substantive forward progress.

Over the course of the next two weeks, Burnside slowly moved his forces into position at Falmouth on the east side of the Rappahannock. As a result of administrative mishandling, the army arrived before the pontoon bridges required to cross over into Fredericksburg. Fearful that the Union would lose the opportunity to control the strategically valuable ridgeline west of the city, Maj. Gen. Edwin Sumner proposed that he lead a small force across the river, rout out the small contingent of Confederate soliders bunkered down in the Fredericksburg, and set the stage for the full Union advance when the pontoon bridges arrived. Burnside was fearful that Sumner would get cut off on the far side of the river, though, and rejected Sumner's plan.

On December 11, after three full weeks after Burnside's army had started arriving at Falmouth, Union engineers started to float six pontoon bridges out over the Rappahannock to set the stage for the Union advance - two bridges were extended directly towards the center of the the town, another downriver near the edge of the town, and three more another mile to the south near where the Deep Run creek connected with the river.

Almost immediately, the teams working on the bridges at the north-most crossing into the center of the town were attacked by Confederate snipers firing from cellars on the far side of the river. When Union artillery crews on Stafford Heights were unable to root out the Confederate contingent in the town, Col. Normal J. Hall convinced Burnside to allow him to take a small force across the river in pontoon boats and protect the landing point on the far side. In the first incidence of urban combat in the war, Hall swept through the city, capturing or killing the relatively small group of Confederate infantrymen.

Union crews were able to float the other four bridges without confronting significant resistance. Burnside's columns filed across the bridges over the course of that afternoon and the morning of the next day. By nightfall on December 12th, the armies were arrayed in two long, parallel lines running at a roughly 45 degree angle from northwest to southeast along the west side of the river.

Burnside issued a series of confusing, noncommittal orders for a general offensive on the Confederate defensive line the next morning, but the details were ill-defined and the Union army stumbled forward in a disjointed, tepid manner when the attack finally started in earnest around midday. Burnside's orders called for Maj. Gen. William B. Franklin to commit some but not all of his troops to an assault on the Confederate left, while Maj. Gen. Edwin V. Sumner would send a single division through Fredericksburg and along Telegraph road to intercept Longstreet's corps on Marye's Heights. Burnside's orders seemed to call for a much less forceful attack than his subordinates had expected, and Franklin decided to send just a single division forward to test out the strength of the Confederate defense. John F. Reynolds, Franlkin's I Corps commander, picked the division of Maj. Gen. George G. Meade to make the attack.

Meade started moving forward at about one o'clock in the afternoon, and stumbled into some good luck. Jackson's Second Corps, spread relatively thin along the long, wooded ridgeline, had left a 600-yard hole in the line near a swampy gap. As Meade advanced, he happened to intercept the Confederate line at this location. His division passed through the gap, climbed up to the tracks of the Richmond Fredericksburg Railroad, and proceeded to quickly flank and overwhelm the brigades of James Lane, James Archer, and Maxcy Gregg.

Brig. Gen. John Gibbon was slated to follow Meade into the fight, but declined to mount a bayonet charge to reinforce Meade's early success. By the time Gibbon started to move forward, Meade was surrounded by Confederate reinforcements that had been sent forward by Taliaferro and Early to contain the chaos that had broken out after the disintegration of the three brigades that had been surprised by Meade's breakthrough. Some of Gibbon's men managed to cross the railroad embankment and reach the top of the ridgeline, but punishing fire from Confederate artillery batteries and the coalescing strength of Jubal Early's reinforcements drove back the Union advances.

With Meade and Gibbon driven back behind the original boundary of the Confederate line, Early decided to capitalize on the disintegration of the Union assault with a counterattack across the railroad, which in turn caused men from the divisions of Hoke, Archer, and Brockenbrough to abandon their entrenchments along the railroad embankment and pursue the fleeing Union infantry.

Although the Confederate advance succeeded in reclaiming all of the ground that had been lost in the aftermath of Meade's breakthrough earlier in the afternoon, the offensive was quickly halted as it approached Richmond Road by a combination of close-range canister shot from Union artillery crews and the arrival of defensive reinforcements lead by Brig. Gens. David Birney and Daniel Sickles. Early drew back into the woods, and the day ended on the Confederate right with a low simmer of artillery fire and minor skirmishes.

Things went even worse for the Union on the Confederate left, where Burnside's army suffered one of the most gruesome and demoralizing defeats of the entire war at the hands of Longstreet's corps, which had taken up a strong defensive position on the high ground west of the town. Two weeks before, Burnside had made a critical strategic error when he refused to allow Sumner to immediately cross the Rappahannock and secure Marye's Heights, a cluster of low hills sitting on the far side of the low, open plain extending to the west behind Fredericksburg.

When Burnside failed to act, Lee had seized the opportunity and rushed the corps of Lt. Gen. James Longstreet to occupy the position. Over the course of the two-week delay that passed before Burnside crossed the river, Longstreet had created an incredibly strong defensive position behind a shoulder-high stone wall running along a stretch of Telegraph Road facing directly out over the plain. Longstreet had stacked multiple lines of riflemen behind the wall, making it possible for one line to fire while the others reloaded. Behind the wall, the gentle slope leading up to the top of the ridgeline was carpeted with Confederate artillery batteries, which could provide nearly uninterrupted coverage of the field below.

To attack the Confederate left, Sumner would first have to traverse this open space between the edge of the town and the stone wall. This would prove to be impossible, and over the course of the roughly six-hour stretch from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Burnside and his field commanders would send 7 brigades to make a total of 14 separate charges on the stone wall, all of which were brutally cut down by the sustained rifle and artillery fire from behind the stone wall, often with casualty rates as high as 50%.

After charges led by Kimball, Andrews, Palmer, Zook, Meagher, Caldwell, Owen, Hall, Sully, and Sturgis failed to reach the wall, Burnside doubled down and ordered Maj. Gen. Joseph Hooker, who was still on the eastern side of the Rappahannock, to cross the river and mount a second wave of attacks on Marye's Heights. Hooker rode down to the front lines, surveyed the carnage, and rode back towards Burnside's headquarters at Phillips House to recommend against continuing the offensive.

While awaiting the result of Hooker's conference with Burnside, Brig. Gen. Charles Griffin committed three of his divisions to charges against the wall, all of which failed. Brig. Gens. Andrew A. Humphreys and George Sykes went in next, and also failed. Meanwhille, Hooker had failed to convince Burnside to stop the charges. After returning to the front line in the last afternoon, he ordered Brig. Gen. George W. Getty and Col. Edward Harland to make oblique, non-frontal assaults on the position, which came closer to success than the previous efforts but still failed to break through Longstreet's line.

Burnside considered the possibility of resuming the assault the next morning, but changed his mind as the casualty reports started coming in from the field. By the end of the day, Lee had lost 5,377 to Burnside's 12,653, and the Union losses had yielded no strategic gain whatsoever. On the night of December 15, the Union army crosses back across the Rappahannock and retreated towards the winter refuge at Falmouth.

_______________________

McPherson, James M. Battle Cry of Freedom: The Civil War Era. New York: Oxford University Press, 1988.

Sutherland, Daniel E. Fredericksburg and Chancellorsville. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1998.

Hamlin, Augustus C. The Battle of Chancellorsville. Bangor, Maine: 1896

Battle of Fredericksburg. (n.d.) In Wikipedia. Retrieved June, 2012, from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_fredericksburg. 

Battle of Fredericksburg. (n.d.) In Wikipedia. Retrieved June, 2012, from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Chancellorsville.

At first, Lee had assumed that Burnside cross over into Fredericksburg before the Confederate army could reposition, and that he would have to fall back and confront Burnside further south. As Burnside tarried on the far side of the river, though, Lee saw an opportunity to occupy the high ground along the ridgeline west of the river and provoke a fight with Burnside as soon as he crossed the river, which had the advantage of moving the action away from Richmond.

Eager to capitalize on the opportunity, Lee immediately moved to position Longstreet's corps on the high ground at Marye's Heights, due west of the town, and stretched Jackson's Second Corps along a seven-mile wooded ridgeline extending south of the town parallel to the river.

title: The Movement to Battle
description:
December of 1862 and January of 1863 were difficult months for the Army of the Potomac. In mid-December, Ambrose Burnside had presided over one of the most gruesome and demoralizing defeats of the entire war at the Battle of Fredericksburg, which had been plagued by administrative mismanagement and tactical errors. At the beginning of November, Burnside started drawing up plans to march his army across the Rappahannock River at Fredericksburg and then sprint south towards the Confederate capitol at Richmond. The plan stalled in the first weeks of December, though, when the pontoon bridges required to cross the Rappahannock arrived almost two weeks late, giving Lee the opportunity to establishes a strong defensive position on the high ground west of the town.

By the time all the pieces were in place for an attack on December 13, Burnside severely underestimated the disadvantage that had been incurred by the delay and ordered a series of catastrophic charges towards the stone wall at the base of Marye's Heights. While Burnside had tarried on the far side of the river, Lt. Gen. James Longstreet had converted the wall into a nearly impregnable defensive position by stacking up multiple lines of riflemen and carpeting the gentle slope leading up to the ridegline with artillery batteries that could provide uninterrupted coverage of the field below. Over the course of the day, Burnside ordered seven divisions to make fourteen separate charges against the position, all of which were brutally cut down by rifle and artillery fire, in many cases with casualty rates as high as 50%.

Reeling from the defeat, Burnside retreated back across the Rappahannock. In a desperate attempt to redeem himself, drew up plans to march his army north, cross the river near Banks Ford, and attack Lee from the other direction. The plan devolved into farce, though, when heavy rains brought the march to a grinding halt in knee-deep mud. Carts of supplies were overturned and pack animals drowned, all in plain sight of the Confederate troops on the far side of the river.

On hearing of Burnside's latest failure, Lincoln decided to cut his losses and replaced Burnside with Maj. Gen. Joseph Hooker, a skilled combat tactician with a reputation for argumentativeness and swagger. With instructions from Lincoln to work as quickly as possible to defeat the Confederate army in the field, Hooker developed an ambitious plan to "double envelop" the Army of Northern Virginia on the far side of the Rappahannock.

Hooker would lead a force of 40,000 men northwest from Fredericksburg and cross the Rappahannock at Kelly's Ford. Maj. Gen. John Sedgwick would take another 40,000 men to the south, cross the river below the town, and resume pressure from the position that Burnside had abandoned after the defeat in December. Meanwhile, Union cavalry under George Stoneman would execute a series of raids south of Chancellorsville in an effort to cut off Confederate supply lines and force Lee into a defensive posture around Richmond, where it was thought that the Union army could provoke him into a decisive battle that would reward the Union's greater numbers and deeper resources.

title: Lee Splits His Army
description:
As Hooker's army started to execute the "double envelopment" maneuver in the last week of April, Lee broke with conventional wisdom about military strategy in the face of a larger opponent. Fearful of the two halves of Hooker's force reuniting around the Confederate army at a single location, Lee decided to split his own army half. Lee considered the larger force approaching from the northwest by way of Kelly's Ford to be the more immediate threat, and decided that it would be easier to stall out the samller force under Sedgwick by sending a small contingent to reoccupy the commanding defensive positions on the high ground west of Fredericksburg.

On May 1, as Lee moved the bulk of his army west from Fredericksburg in the direction of the Chancellorsville crossroads, Brig. Gen. William Barksdale was left to defend Marye's Heights and Maj. Gen Jubal Early was left on Prospect Hill south of the town. Although these outposts chipped away at the core of Lee's already outnumbered force as it moved west to confront Hooker at Chancellorsville, the defensive buffer provided by Early and Barksdale would give Lee the flexibility and confidence to make a series of risky maneuvers on the roads running through the dense woods surrounding Chancellorsville the next morning.

Lee's army started to collide with Hooker's defenses near the end of the day on May 1 as columns under the command of McLaws, Anderson, and Rodes advanced west along Plank Road and the Turnpike. In the skirmishes that followed, Hooker's units gained a series of positions that put the Union army in a strong offensive posture. Perhaps fearful of stumbling into a repeat of the gruesome charges on Marye's Heights at the Battle of Fredericksburg, though, Hooker suddenly decided to cancel the attacks on the advancing Confederate columns and withdraw to a defensive positions around the Chancellorsville crossroads, a decision that enraged many of his subordinates, who saw an opportunity inflict significant damage on Lee's exposed army.

title: Lee Splits His Army Again
description:
The day before, as the Confederate army prepared to start the march towards Chancellorsville, Hotchkiss had been dispatched to make a series of sketches of the tangle of small roads through the dense woods surrounding Chancellorsville and the Wilderness.

On the morning of May 2, Hotchkiss presented these maps to Lee and Jackson at the Confederate headquarters near the intersection of Plank Road and Furnace Road. Confederate scouts had reported that the Union right flank, under the command of Maj. Gen. Oliver O. Howard, was hanging out into the woods west of the town, facing south and completely unprepared for a flanking attack from the west. Based in large part on the information about the surrounding road network contained in Hotchkiss's maps, Jackson proposed a risky maneuver: Instead of demonstrating directly against the formidable Union defenses facing out towards the current Confederate position east of the town, Jackson would lead the entire Second Corps, about 28,000 men, on an all-day, fourteen-mile flanking march along Furnace Road, which traced out a wide arc south of Chancellorsville before veering back to the north and intercepting the Old Turnpike west of the Chancellorsville crossroads. Once in position, Jackson would attack Howard from the west and drive as far along the Turnpike as possible before nightfall.

This was a risky plan - Lee was trusting not only that Jackson would be able to successfully complete the flanking march without revealing himself to the Union defenses, but also that Hooker and Sedgwick would stay more or less on the defensive throughout the course of the entire day as Jackson's columns moved into position west of the town. A number of things could go wrong - If Sedgwick were to have launched an offensive back at Fredericksburg and broken through the defenses of Early and Barksdale, the rest of Lee's army would be left completely exposed from the rear and surrounded on both sides by Hooker and Sedgwick, the exact scenario that Lee was trying to avoid. And if Hooker were to have decided to reverse course and resume the offensive that he had abandoned the day before, the Lee would be enormously outnumbered, his force diminished by the two successive divisions.

title: Sickles Sees Jackson's March
description:
As Jackson's columns marched through the woods along Furnace Road, infantrymen in the division of Brig. Gen. David B. Birney observed the passing Confederate soldiers. Birney ordered his artillery to open fire on the road, and Daniel E. Sickles, the commander of the Union III Corps, rode back to Hooker's headquarters at the Chancellor mansion and reported the movement in person. Hooker suspected either a retreat or a flanking attempt, and sent orders to Howard in the woods west of the Wilderness that there was credible evidence that Lee was trying to launch a flank attack and that the XI Corps should be prepared for action.

Meanwhile, Hooker granted Sickles permission to mount a small offensive against Jackson march on Furnace Road. Sickles sent the division of Brig. Gen. David B. Birney and two battalions of Col. Hiram Berdan's sharpshooters south to intercept the Second Corps. But almost all of Jackson's men had already passed by the time the Union force arrived at the road, and Jackson had left behind the 23rd Georgia Infantry to resist any Union attempt to attack from behind. The 23rd was driven back and eventually defeated and captured by Birney and Berdan, but the skirmish succeeded in preventing substantive damage to the Second Corps.

title: Jackson's Original Plan of Attack
description: Jackson originally planned to make the attack by way of Orange Plank Road, but as the Second Corps moved into position it became clear that Howard's defenses were facing perpendicular to the road, and that an attack from that direction would amount to a frontal attack on Howard's line. Instead, Jackson decided to continue for another two miles and join with the Old Turnpike directly west of Howard's position.

title: Jackson Attacks
description:
Earlier in the afternoon, after Sickles had reported the movement of the Confederate columns along Furnace Road, Hooker had sent orders to Howard instructing him to prepare for the possibility of a flank attack from the west. Howard had essentially rejected the intelligence, insisting that Union cavalry scouts had been active in the areas where the movement had been reported. Although Howard responded that he was taking action to prepare for an attack, he did virtually nothing all afternoon, and his position was almost completely unprotected by the time the Second Corps moved into position in the late afternoon. Howard's position basically just petered out into the woods to the west - the Union flank was not shielded by any kind of natural barrier, and all of Howard's lines were oriented to the south.

At about 5:30 p.m., after almost ten hours of marching, Jackson's force of 20,000 men attacked eastward along the Turnpike, completely surprising the soliders of the XI Corps, many of whom were cooking dinner when the attack began. In spite of the skillful efforts of Maj. Gen. Carl Schurz to reorient the Union defensive and the personal bravery of Howard's last-minute effort to scrape together a substantive defense of the position, Jackson's men made about 1.25 miles of progress along the Turnpike to within about a mile of the Chancellorsville crossroads by nightfall, completely scattering the Union defenses as they went.

As darkness fell, the Confederate assault became increasingly disjointed and confused as it moved through the woods near Old Schoolhouse. The advance was halted and the lines reformed around 9 o'clock, just as the front line approached the positions of Sickles' men, who had returned from their efforts earlier in the day to interfere with Jackson's march and taken up the high ground on Hazel Grove. In the aftermath of Jackson's assault, Sickles' force was the only significant barrier between the Second Corps and Lee's troops to the southeast of Chancellorsville.

title: Jackson Mortally Wounded
description:
At about 9:00 p.m. after the Confederate advance had halted in the woods around the Wilderness, Jackson led a small party out onto Plank Road on a scouting mission to evaluate the possibility of mounting a second attack during the night in an effort to capitalize on the confusion in the Union ranks wrought by the afternoon's attack.

As he returned to the Confederate lines, Major John D. Barry of the Eighteenth North Carolina Regiment mistook Jackson's party Federal cavalry and ordered his line to open fire. Jackson was shot twice in the left arm and once in the right hand; the injured arm was amputated, but Jackson died of pneumonia eight days later on May 10.

title: Porter Takes Control of Hazel Grove
description:
Despite the overwhelming victory of Jackson's Second Corps over Howard's XI Corps the night before, Lee was still faced with a tactically challenging situation the next morning. The two halves of Lee's army - Jackson's Second Corps (now under the command of J. E. B. Stuart, after both Jackson and his second in command A. P. Hill were wounded the night before) and the force of 15,000 men that Lee personally commanded to the southeast of the town were still separated by the formidable defensive position held by Sickles corps on Hazel Grove, a bluff sitting southwest of the Chancellorsville crossroads. Unless Lee could find a way to reunite the two halves of his army, either individually would be vulnerable to aggressive action from Hooker, who outnumbered the Confederate force significantly.

Apparently not understanding the tactical importance of Sickles' fortifications on Hazel Grove, Hooker ordered Sickles to abandon the position in the early hours of May 3 and form a new line running perpendicular to Plank Road, presumably in an effort to shore up the entrenchments around the Chancellorsville crossroads. Stuart understood the value of Hazel Grove and sent a small force early in the morning to try to flank Sickles and occupy the high ground looking out over Chancellorsville. Sickles vacated the position just in time for the arrival of Early's attackers, and Col. Porter Alexander quickly transformed the bluff into a powerful artillery battery with expansive coverage of the horseshoe-shaped Union position spread out below around the town.

title: Lee Closes in on Hooker at Chancellorsville
description:
Early organized the bulk of his force into three long lines running perpendicular to the Trunpike - Brig. Gen. Henry Heth in front, followed by Raleigh Colston, followed in the rear by Robert Rodes. The main attack started at about 5:30 - the three lines of infantry slammed against the powerful Federal entrenchments around the Chancellor house, resulting in some of the most intense and chaotic fighting of the war. In spite of the fierce defensive fighting by the Federal lines around the town, the successive waves of Confederate attackers combined with the punishing artillery fire from Porter's batteries on Hazel Grove overwhelmed the Union fortifications.

At around 9 a.m., Hooker was standing next to a large porch column when it was hit by a confederate artillery round, briefly knocking Hooker unconscious and forcing him to fall back to the rear and issue the order to abandon the town and retreat towards a defensive position along Mineral Spring Road, which would protect his line of retreat back over the Rappahannock. Around the same time, Lee started his attack in earnest from the south of the town, moving a long line running perpendicular to Plank Road north towards the town. By 10 a.m., Lee effectively controlled the Chancellorsville crossroads.

title: Sedgwick Breaks Through at Fredericksburg
description:
Meanwhile, back at Fredericksburg, Sedgwick had successfully moved the small force that Lee had left to fortify the high ground west of the town and give his force at Chancellorsville the opportunity to challenge Hooker before the to halves of his army could reunite. After Jackson's successful attack the night before, Hooker had sent orders to Sedgwick instructing him to break through the Confederate defenses and march west along Plank Road to support his besieged position at Chancellorsville.

Sedgwick started his artillery bombardment at about 6 a.m., right around the same time that Stuart and Porter were resuming their attack on Hooker's entrenchments around Chancellorsville. Although Sedgwick originally intended to focus his attack south of the town around the same areas where Union troops had succeeded in temporarily breaking through in the first Battle of Fredericksburg in December of the last year, a series of logistical hitches in the movement to battle that morning forced Sedgwick to abandon that plan and instead execute a direct, frontal assault on the stone wall at Marye's Heights.

At first, it appeared as if Sedgwick was falling into the same trap that had resulted in Burnside's gruesome defeat in December - two charges were pushed back with heavy casualties by Barksdale's riflemen lined up along the wall. In the late morning, though, two of Sedgwick's brigades managed to break through the Confederate line near Hazel Run and flank Barksdale's defenses. Soon after, a third frontal charge on Marye's Heights succeeded in reaching the wall, and Sedgwick's force poured through the Confederate line and was presented with a more or less open road leading to Chancellorsville.

title: Wilcox and McLaws Stop Sedgwick at Salem Church
description:
After breaking through the Confederate line along the high ground west of Fredericksburg, Sedgwick decided to immediately start marching west along Plank Road towards the Chancellorsville crossroads, where Hooker was being driven back to the north by the sustained pressure from infantry under Stuart and Lee and the Confederate artillery batteries on Hazel Grove. During the attack, the Alabama Brigade of Cadmus Wilcox had been cut off from the rest of the defensive line and pushed north. After Sedgwick broke through, Wilcox decided to move his brigade west along River Road, which ran roughly parallel to Plank Road to the north, and then descend down by way of small connector roads and intercept Sedgwick's march.

Over the course of the next several hours, Wilcox impeded the march with a series of flimsy and outnumbered defensive lines that succeeded in slowing - but not stopping - the Federal columns. When Lee heard about the Union breakthrough at Fredericksburg, he had dispatched two of McLaws brigades to march east along the Old Turnpike, merge onto Plank Road, and join with Wilcox and lay down a decisive defensive line to halt the oncoming Federal troops.

McLaws' forward movement and Wilcox's retreat met near the Salem Church, roughly mid-way between Chancellorsville and Fredericksburg and formed a strong defensive line. After a lengthy exchange of artillery fire, the division under William Brooks, which had spearheaded the Union march down Plank Road, attacked the newly consolidated line under McLaws and Wilcox at about 5:30. Successful at first, Brooks was pushed back by definitively by a Confederate counterattack, and by nightfall Sedgwick had failed to push through and connect with Hooker's battered force at Chancellorsville. In total, the two armies had suffered 21,357 casualties, making May 3 the second bloodiest day of the war, second only to the Battle of Antietam. Created with WorkFlowy.com

title: Early Retakes Marye's Heights
description: Aware that his failure to successfully contain Sedgwick at Fredericksburg the day before had put the Confederate army in a somewhat precarious position, Jubal Early proposed to Lee that he lead an attack first thing the next morning to retake Marye's Heights from Gibbon, which would then make it possible to surround the horseshoe-shaped defensive line south of the river that Sedgwick and Brooks had established after being stopped on Plank Road the day before. Lee approved the plan, and Early launched his attack at about 7:30 a.m. Gibbon, apparently unsure of his role in the new Union defensive position below the river, had done nothing to fortify the heights, and Early had no trouble reoccupying the ridgeline.

title: Anderson Marches to Reinforce McLaws
description:
After retaking the position west of Fredericksburg, Early had succeeded in establishing a Confederate line that surrounded the horseshoe-shaped Union defenses on the east, south, and west. Instead of immediately capitalizing on the situation, though, the Confederate attack lulled - on the Union right, McLaws was sluggish in his efforts to get his troops into position for attack, and sent a message back to Lee in Chancellorsville asking for more troops. Lee responded by sending three divisions under the command of Richard Anderson on a long march along River Road to meet up with McLaws on the western end of the Confederate line.

This movement, combined with other logistical foot-dragging along the Confederate line, occupied most of the day - much to the ire of Early and Lee, who had hoped to move quickly and destroy as much of Sedgwick's army as possible before it had time to move back across the Rappahannock. Created with WorkFlowy.com

title: Lee Pushes Sedgwick Across the Rappahannock
Early and Lee resume the attack on Chancellorsville
Burnside's planned route towards Richmond along the Richmond - Fredericksburg Railroad
description: If Burnside had succeeded in breaking through Lee's defenses at Fredericksburg, he planned to make a sprint towards the Confederate capitol along the Richmond - Fredericksburg Railroad.

title: Lee and Jackson plan the flanking march using Hotchkiss's maps
description:
On May 1, 1863, the day before the breakout of the Battle of Chancellorsville, Jedediah Hotchkiss had been dispatched to makes a series of sketches of the tangle of small roads through the dense woods surrounding Chancellorsville and the Wilderness.

On the morning of May 2, Hotchkiss presented these maps to Lee and Jackson at the Confederate headquarters near the intersection of Plank Road and Furnace Road. Confederate scouts had reported that the Union right flank, under the command of Maj. Gen. Oliver O. Howard, was hanging out into the woods west of the town, facing south and completely unprepared for a flanking attack from the west. Based in large part on the information about the surrounding road network contained in Hotchkiss's maps, Jackson proposed a risky maneuver: Instead of demonstrating directly against the formidable Union defenses facing out towards the current Confederate position east of the town, Jackson would lead the entire Second Corps, about 28,000 men, on an all-day, fourteen-mile flanking march along Furnace Road, which traced out a wide arc south of Chancellorsville before veering back to the north and intercepting the Old Turnpike west of the Chancellorsville crossroads. Once in position, Jackson would attack Howard from the west and drive as far along the Turnpike as possible before nightfall.

This was a risky plan - Lee was trusting not only that Jackson would be able to successfully complete the flanking march without revealing himself to the Union defenses, but also that Hooker and Sedgwick would stay more or less on the defensive throughout the course of the entire day as Jackson's columns moved into position west of the town. A number of things could go wrong - If Sedgwick were to have launched an offensive back at Fredericksburg and broken through the defenses of Early and Barksdale, the rest of Lee's army would be left completely exposed from the rear and surrounded on both sides by Hooker and Sedgwick, the exact scenario that Lee was trying to avoid. And if Hooker were to have decided to reverse course and resume the offensive that he had abandoned the day before, the Lee would be enormously outnumbered, his force diminished by the two successive divisions.

At about 5:30 p.m., after almost ten hours of marching, Jackson's force of 20,000 men attacked eastward along the Turnpike, completely surprising the soliders of the XI Corps, many of whom were cooking dinner when the attack began. In spite of the skillful efforts of Maj. Gen. Carl Schurz to reorient the Union defensive and the personal bravery of Howard's last-minute effort to scrap together a substantive defense of the position, Jackson's men made about 1.25 miles of progress along the Turnpike to within about a mile of the Chancellorsville crossroads by nightfall, completely scattering the Union defenses as they went.

title: Jackson mortally wounded by friendly fire
description:
At about 9:00 p.m. after the Confederate advance had halted in the woods around the Wilderness, Jackson led a small party out onto Plank Road on a scouting mission to evaluate the possibility of mounting a second attack during the night in an effort to capitalize on the confusion in the Union ranks wrought by the afternoon's attack.

As he returned to the Confederate lines, Major John D. Barry of the Eighteenth North Carolina Regiment mistook Jackson's party Federal cavalry and ordered his line to open fire. Jackson was shot twice in the left arm and once in the right hand; the injured arm was amputated, but Jackson died of pneumonia eight days later on May 10.

title: Lee holds the Chancellorsville crossroads
description:
By the evening of May 3, 1863, Lee had managed to encircle Sedgwick's entrenchments at the Chancellorsville crossroads and drive the Union lines north into a horseshoe-shaped defensive position extending all the way north to the Rappahannock River. The day before, Thomas "Stonewall" Jackson had used Hotchkiss's maps of the network of roads running through the woods south and west of the town to plan and execute a daring, 14-mile flanking march that dipped far below the Union lines and put Jackson into position to launch a devastating flank attack on the Union right, which completely collapsed on the evening of May 2.

Although Jackson was gunned down by friendly fire when returning from a late-night scouting ride after the initial assault, Lee and J. E. B. Stuart, Jackson's replacement, resumed the offensive early on the morning of the 3rd. The Union lines, pushed back and clustered into a tight knot around the Chancellor House from the previous night's attack, mounted a fierce defense of the position and held Lee off for the first part of the morning, but eventually the punishing artillery fire from Hazel Grove wore down Hooker's defenses and the Union army abandoned the crossroads and retreated north towards the river.

title: Confederate position on the evening of May 3
Sedgwick retreats to the north and protects his line of retreat
description:
Reeling from the devastating defeat at Chancellorsville, Hooker (who had himself been injured when he was leaning on a wooden column that was hit by a Confederate artillery round, knocking him unconscious for over an hour) pulled his force back into a strong defensive position north of the town that secured his line of retreat back over the Rappahannock.

There was little action near Chancellorsville over the course of the day on May 3 - the focus of the battle had moved east, back in the direction of Fredericksburg, where Sedgwick had managed to break through the defenses of Jubal Early and William Barksdale, who had been left to defend the high ground west of the town.

Lee shifted the center of his force east to assist in the effort to delay Sedwick as he sprinted belatedly towards Chancellorsville in hopes of relieving Hooker's besieged force. Sedgwick made strong progress for the first half of the afternoon, but was eventually stopped near Salem Church, about three miles east of Chancellorsville along Plank Road. Sedgwick north retreated into defensive position below the river and sent repeated requests to Chancellorsville asking for assistance, but Hooker, sitting quiet in the position shown here north of Chancellorsville, refused to send significant reinforcements.

The following day, on May 4, the Confederate army retook the high ground at Marye's Heights and attacked Sedgwick, driving back across the river. Hooker, seeing that his effort to "double envelop" the Confederate army from two directions had failed, pulled his own force back across the river in the early morning hours of May 5.

title: Hooker pulls back across the Rappahannock
"Sunday p.m. + Monday"
